instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3476: What is 820-3476? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7501: What is U7501? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V3_S5,  PP3V3_S3,  PP3V3_S0,  PP5V_S5,  PP5V_S4,  PP5V_S0.
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a not turning on.
threads.message:
Hi, 

Logic board was water damaged in <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> area. Cleaned, replaced <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> and <RESISTOR>R7537</RESISTOR> <CAPACITOR>C7537</CAPACITOR> <CAPACITOR>C7536</CAPACITOR> that were burnt. Now seems that i am getting all reail ok but dont getting ALL SYS GOOD. 


CHecked and seems that board tries to enter S0 state once connect adapter. <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> is 1.7V and <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> 0 V.  As i see i will not get sys good while <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> is not activated. 


Bad <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> ??? ALready replaced it twice.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a not turning on.
threads.message:
Post voltage on big coils.
Also check for short on all power rails which don't even pulse.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a not turning on.
threads.message:
L7130 - 12.6V

L7520, L7320/10, L3095 are 0V

L7560 - 3.3V


<SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> is shorted - 1.2 Ohms to ground,

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a not turning on.
threads.message:
There are other coils I was expected to know the voltage; like PCH and DDR (L7630, L7430)...

L7310/20 could be low ohm to ground as normal; compare with known good working board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a not turning on.
threads.message:
Both are 0V.

L7430 is 200 Ohms to ground and L7630 is 20 to ground.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a not turning on.
threads.message:
Do you get any pulse at L7520?
Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and check that.
Check all other coils at same moment.

"Now seems that i am getting all reail ok"
How that?
You've said to get only <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>; didn't say anything about pulse (at least) on other coils...
